abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.para: This thesis introduces the core component of the Haskell XML Toolbox: a validating XML parser that supports almost fully the &xmlspecl; WWW01. The thesis presents how a validating XML parser and XML processing applications can be implemented by using filter functions as a uniform design.

The &hxtl; is a collection of tools for processing XML with Haskell. It is itself purely written in Haskell. The Toolbox is a project of the University of Applied Sciences Wedel, initialized by Prof. Dr. Uwe Schmidt.

The &hxtl; bases on the ideas of HaXml WWW21 and HXML WWW25, but introduces a more general approach for processing XML with Haskell. It uses a generic data model for representing XML documents, including the DTD subset and the document subset. This data model makes is possible to use filter functions as a uniform design of XML processing applications. Libraries with filters and combinators are provided for processing this data model.

listitem.para: hdom - Core data types and functions for processing XML with Haskell
hvalidator - Modules for validating XML documents

abstract.para: Prof. Dr. Uwe Schmidt wrote the basic parser and core functions. His master student Christine Nickel wrote the package hxslt, his master student Martin Schmidt wrote the package hvalidator and some parts of the parser.

Malcolm Wallace and Colin Runciman wrote HaXml WWW21, a collection of utilities for using Haskell and XML together. The &hxtl; is based on their idea of using filter combinators for processing XML with Haskell.

Joe English wrote HXML WWW25, a non-validating XML parser in Haskell. His idea of validating XML by using derivatives of regular expressions WWW26 was implemented in the validation functions of this software.
